sect1.title: Dos and Don’ts
sect1.para: As mentioned earlier, many patients with SSRD have undergone a long history of partly disappointing interactions with the healthcare system. Clinicians conducting interviews with individuals with SSRD should be aware that the diagnostic sessions do not just have the purpose to make a diagnosis but to build a therapeutic relationship and to facilitate patients’ readiness to adopt an interdisciplinary treatment approach including psychological interventions. The following Dos and Don’ts shall help guide clinicians through the diagnostic process.

sect2.title: Dos
Don’ts
sect2.para: Don’t tell patients that they “will have to live with it” or that “symptoms are produced in their mind or brain.” Don’t use terms that imply a biopsychosocial nature of the symptom too early in the interaction with the patient, such as “psychosomatic,” “psychogenic,” “somatoform,” or “psychological/mental.” Don’t make decisions for the patient or fall into body-mind dichotomous thinking (e. g., “We cannot find a medical cause, for this reason your symptom is psychosomatic”). Avoid providing reassurance that your patient does not have an organic disease.
